results.title: Atomic medicine
results.creator_credit: CBS, Isaac Kleinerman, Burton Benjamin and Peter Poor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Among the peaceful uses of the atom is the application of atomic radiation in medical research, diagnosis and treatment. Radiation “tagging and tracing” is a valuable technique in ascertaining the sizes and shapes of various glands such as the thyroid. Treatment of cancers in localized regions of the body is one of the most effective deterrents of the disease. This film points out how continuing research hopes to improve on methods now in use.

results.title: Atomic juggernaut
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Walford Hewitson, Tom Daly and Eugene Boyko
results.brief_description: In India they call it Anushkati - the atomic juggernaut - a modern miracle brought from Canada to light an entire region. This film shows the strange procession made by the calandria, the heart of the nuclear reactor, hauled by huge diesel tractors from the seaport in India to the proposed site of the reactor, along a roadway specially prepared beforehand. Everywhere the juggernaut passed, ancient life stopped for a moment to witness the arrival of this new deity.

results.title: Atomic footprints
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr Productions and Pip Starr
results.brief_description:
The debate surrounding the production of nuclear energy goes back to the bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II. Since then, the proliferation of nuclear energy and weapons has been used as a deterrant, a bolstering of military power and, in the early 2000’s, as a solution to combat global warming.

With the Prime Minister John Howard’s comments regarding not ruling out atomic power stations, this documentary considers the implications to the environment, the people living on the land, our health and our future.

results.title: Atomic energy explained
results.creator_credit: Film Producers Guild and British Information Services
results.brief_description: A practical outline of atomic energy and its peaceful applications. Studies the structure of atomic particles and shows how energy can be released from them to produce atomic power. Also illustrates how radio-isotopes are being put to valuable use in modern industry and medicine. No other credits available.

results.title: Atomic achievement
results.creator_credit: Rayant Pictures, Anthony Gilkison and John Reeve
results.brief_description: An account of Britain’s vast nuclear power program for a new industrial era, and of progress to date. Operational centres visited by the film include Calder Hall, the first full-scale nuclear power station; the great atomic research centre at Harwell; the atomic factories at Springfields, Capenhurst and Windscale; and the “fast breeder-reactor” under construction at Dounreay. Animated diagrams explain the working of a nuclear reactor.

results.title: Atom and agriculture
results.brief_description: The importance, types and principal uses of radio-active isotopes in agricultural research; radio-active cobalt and calcium used to study growth and hereditary characteristics in plants; radio-active carbon-dioxide used to study the chemistry of food production; radio-sulphur used in the study of wool growth; use of radio-active calcium and phosphorous in research work on egg production. No other credits available.

results.title: Atoll life in Kiribati
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Cinema Enterprises and Oliver Howes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
This series of films examines traditional lifestyles on the different Pacific islands. This particular film looks at the traditions observed by the 64,000 people who live on the sixteen islands of Kiribati.

results.title: Atmospheric science
results.creator_credit: Coronet, Bill Walker Productions, Joel Marks and Mel Waskin
results.brief_description: Dramatic cinematography and timelapse photography convey the drama of nature’s spectacular display. ‘Global winds’ demonstrates global circulation and how these movements depend on great convection cells set in motion by differences in temperature. ‘Clouds and precipitation’ looks at how clouds form and vanish and explains the differences between the types of clouds we see. ‘Violent storms’ examines the causes and effects of thunderstorms, thunderheads and tornadoes. Suitable for Upper Primary and Secondary level students.

results.title: Atmosphere in motion. - Revised edition.
results.brief_description: Recent changes in the ozone layer have refocused attention on the importance of the atmosphere to life on our planet. Pictures from space show the swirling wisps and bands in the mass of air surrounding the Earth. Convection cells, the Coriolis Effect, the structure and composition of the atmosphere, and the invisible forces that keep the atmosphere in continuous motion are illustrated through demonstrations, laboratory experiments and animation. A well presented introduction to the atmosphere which is ideal for background information on the Greenhouse effect.
